data.body:

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create new "test.json" file
2. Paste the following...
{

}

data.title: Not able to specify a -- (double hyphen) as args in launch.json, while debugging with lldb
data.body:

e.g. ./binary  arg1  --  sub_arg1

"args": ["arg1  -- sub_arg1"]

How do I trick launch.json into thinking that -- is an actual argument to the binary.

data.title: Unreadable search input box (too tight)
data.body:
Hello!

It looks like that when I open the search bar (command+F) it is initialized with not enough horizontal space, so the input field it is barely visible, and nothing I type inside it is readable unless I manually give more room to it.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3191993/30612181-0efa9d94-9d84-11e7-9131-85db3711aa45.png)

Even opening the search box with some selected text gives the same behavior

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3191993/30612221-245bc924-9d84-11e7-9d79-06af7de791a5.png)

If you manually resize the input box the new size is kept until restart.
If you need additional info I'm at your service

- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: Mac Os Sierra 10.12.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open any file
2. open the search box (command + F)

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Unknown unicode characters written back as different hex than they are read in as

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I didn't see an existing one like this so here we are.

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: Win7 Pro

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Have a UTF-8 file with unicode U+0091 in it.
2. Open file in VS code to have it displayed as �
3. Make change somewhere in file other than the hex 91 character and save file
4. Open in notepad++ to see the character is now different as the hex in the file for U+0091 has been rewritten as � (0xEFBFBD) from the 0x91 it was previously.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Warning about merge conflicts when all conflicts are resolved?
data.body:
- Have a file with merge conflicts
- Resolve all conflicts
- Click `+` to stage the file
- Get merge conflicts warning:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/323878/30608173-5d25b8a8-9d2c-11e7-8f0f-981a163eca61.png)

This makes me think that I missed a conflict, but all are resolved. Is it a bug or is it supposed to be a general confirmation message? I think this is new but I don't resolve conflicts that often.

data.title: Javascript "Rename symbol" does not rename destructured variables
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:38:23.027Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: Extensions are disabled
---

Steps to Reproduce:
Given the following code: 

```Javascript
let obj = { x: 'x', y: 'y', z: 'z' };
const { x, y, z } = obj;
console.log(x, y, z);  // "x" "y" "z"
```

If I execute the "Rename Symbol" command while the cursor is on the `x` property of `obj` and rename the property, the destructured variable is not renamed and the code is left in a invalid state.

```Javascript
let obj = { newNameX: 'x', y: 'y', z: 'z' };
const { x, y, z } = obj;
console.log(x, y, z); // undefined "y" "z"
```
I would expect the `x` variable to be renamed to `newNameX` and the usage of `x` in the `console.log` to also be renamed.

This problem also exists for Typescript code.
This appears to have been reported and fixed once before (#6227).


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Closes #27408 - Adds ViewColumn.Active
data.body:
This should close https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/27408, since we don't want to change the default -- there is now an explicit way for an extension to target the active view column.

Once this is in, the Git extension can be updated to use this re: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/34459

FYI, I used `-1` to help avoid any falsey issues.

/cc @jrieken @bpasero

data.title: Workspace folder picker command (for #32936)
data.body:
fixes https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/32936

Introduces a simple new command `vscode.pickWorkspace` to pick a `WorkspaceFolder` via quick pick.

data.title: Import statement snippet inconsistent between .ts and .tsx files
data.body:
1. Create a .ts file
2. Type `import`
3. Press tab to activate the "import statement" snippet

Expected and actual: completes to `import {  } from "module";`

1. Create a .tsx file (TypeScript + JSX)
2. Type `import`
3. Press tab to activate the "import statement" snippet

Actual: completes to `import name = require('');`

Expected: completes to `import {  } from "module";`

Is there any reason why the snippet is inconsistent between .ts and .tsx files?

data.title: Bash syntax highlighting bug when using comments in backticks
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: MacOS Sierra

**Steps to Reproduce:**

I use the following style to insert inline documentation for long bash commands and their cryptic args.

```bash
foo                             \
  -d `# we use d for something` \
  -c `# we use c for something` \
  ...
```

The same snippet on vscode breaks syntax highlighting in other parts of the code, because it doesn't correctly detect the comment statement inside backticks. Use keywords (`for`, `in`), or quotes inside the comment statements to see the bug.

data.title: Forward cancellation to underlying task
data.body: I noticed that ThrottledDelayer doesn't forward cancellation to the underlying promise (which is what I expected it to do). It seems like it should.

data.title: Feature request: Argument placeholders after function autocompletion?
data.body:
First of all, Thank You for this awesome code editor!

In Sublime when I press tab and a function is autocompleted, it provides argument placeholders. I miss that feature so much in VSCode and I'm sure everybody who migrated from Sublime will wish that feature. 
![sublime snip](https://i.imgur.com/1CkZM8r.jpg)

There is this setting in the dart extension, but I want it globally, for all the languages I use.
![dart extension settings](https://i.imgur.com/CGlx5PS.jpg)

data.title: Update vs code Fedora
data.body:
I have fedora 26, Vs code


    Version 1.16.0
    Commit 787b31c0474e6165390b5a5989c9619e3e16f953
    Date 2017-09-06T16:19:37.192Z
    Shell 1.7.3
    Renderer 58.0.3029.110
    Node 7.9.0
    Architecture x64

And it keeps showing 

[![enter image description here][1]][1]

In the main menu too. I tried updating it like [this][2]

    sudo rpm --import https://packages.microsoft.com/keys/microsoft.asc
    sudo sh -c 'echo -e "[code]\nname=Visual Studio Code\nbaseurl=https://packages.microsoft.com/yumrepos/vscode\nenabled=1\ngpgcheck=1\ngpgkey=https://packages.microsoft.com/keys/microsoft.asc" > /etc/yum.repos.d/vscode.repo'
    
    Then update the package cache and install the package using dnf (Fedora 22 and above):
    
    dnf check-update
    sudo dnf install code


Do I have the latest version? Is it a bug in vs code that keeps notifying for updates? Or do I have to update it in some other way?

  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/gonhG.png
  [2]: https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/setup/linux#_rhel-fedora-and-centos-based-distributions

---|---|---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install VS Code on macOS Sierra (10.12.6).
2. When update notification appears in bottom left, right click and select Restart to Update.
3. Wait for application to close, do its work and restart.

The update notification appears again, regardless of how many times it is told to update.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: webpack-dev-server doesn’t pick up changes when editing with VSCode, other editor works
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:26:20.018Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.10.0-35-generic
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-eslint|dba|1.3.1
prettier-vscode|esb|0.23.1
sublime-keybindings|ms-|2.9.1

(1 theme extensions excluded)


---

In a project, I have a `package.json` defining `npm start` as a script to run `node_modules/.bin/webpack-dev-server --config webpack.dev.js`. Whenever I save a changed JS/CSS file, this will create a new JS/CSS bundle and reload the application that is open in a browser tab.

When changing a file within VSCode, the webpack-dev-server does not detect a change, either when using the integrated or an external terminal.

When changing a file within another editor, everything works as expected. But there is a twist. When I start VSCode now and run the npm task from there (interrupting the other one before), it works in VSCode as well.

**But**, when I close VSCode and open it again, running the npm task again, it no longer works.

I don’t know how I could make this easily reproducable for you. Also, I’m very sorry as this is not really a helpful report. Maybe you can give me some advice how I can pin this one down properly. Maybe it’s not an issue after all.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: **Yes**
